courses.name: Basic Pathology
courses.description: Provides nonmedical students with a general understanding of the essential nature of disease, including mechanisms of its development and cause/effect relationships.
courses.prerequisites: 5 hours Biological Science or equivalent and 5 hours Chemistry or PTH_AS 2201

courses.name: Human Anatomy Lecture
courses.description: A systems-based survey of human gross anatomy including structure, function and history. Internet access required: lectures and assignments will be online.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Minimum cumulative MU GPA of 2.5 required

courses.name: Human Anatomy Laboratory
courses.description: A systems-based survey of human gross anatomy. Internet access required: most materials will be online. One on-campus laboratory meeting per week. Graded A-F only.

courses.name: Cytology Female Genital Tract
courses.description: A definitive study of normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring within the organ system by means of light microscopy with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Respiratory Cytology
courses.description: A definitive study of the normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring within the system by means of light microscopy, with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Cytology of Body Fluids
courses.description: Normal and abnormal cellular changes within pleural, peritoneal, pericardial and cerebrospinal fluids by means of light microscopy, with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Gastrointestinal Cytology
courses.description: A definitive study of the normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring within the system by means of light microscopy, with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Oral Cytology
courses.description: Studies normal and abnormal cellular changes within the oral cavity and oropharynx by means of light microscopy, with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Urinary Cytology
courses.description: Studies normal and abnormal cellular morphology from kidney, ureter and bladder samples, with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Special Problems in Cytology
courses.description: Relating hematologic morphologic findings in conventional body fluid cytology; also review of techniques used in chromosome cultures and karyotyping, with emphasis on sex-related abnormalities.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Medical Technology I
courses.description: Emphasizes diseases and basic laboratory methods used in clinical laboratory areas: microbiology, hematology, immunology, virology, tissue typing, blood banking and chemistry.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Medical Technology II
courses.description: Continuation of PTH_AS 3400.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Medical Technology III
courses.description: Continuation of PTH_AS 3400 and PTH_AS 3410.

courses.name: Clinical Practicum
courses.description: Presentation and application of concepts and laboratory method used in areas of immunochemistry, toxicology, mycology, uranalysis and cytogenetics.

courses.name: Hemostasis
courses.description: Lectures and laboratory exercises in basic theory and techniques of hemostasis including platelet function and disorders, plasma coabulation system, acquired and inherited themostatic disorders.

courses.name: Clinical Immunology
courses.description: Antigen-antibody reactions and their role in determining infectious, auto-allergic and inflammatory disease states.

courses.name: Blood Banking
courses.description: Principles and techniques of transfusion practices related through lectures and experience in the blood bank laboratory.

courses.name: Clinical Hematology
courses.description: Lectures and laboratory regarding procedures for diagnosing hematolgic disorders. Experience in collection of specimens from patients; staining, counting and identifying blood and bone marrow cells.

courses.name: Clinical Microbiology
courses.description: Diagnostic procedures related to the isolation and identification to infectious microorganisms; bacteria and parasites. Emphasis on human pathogens and their sensitivity patterns with commonly used antibiotics.

courses.name: Clinical Chemistry
courses.description: Principles of quantitative analysis applied to the measurement of substances  in biological fluids. Significance of these findings in the diagnosis and treatment of disease.

courses.name: Principles of Management and Education
courses.description: Lectures and discussion of management techniques and theories used in supervising laboratory personnel. Analysis of educational objectives and exam questions.

courses.name: Research and Instructional Techniques
courses.description: Involves library and laboratory research. Includes development of oral and written communications skills.

courses.name: Problems in Medical Technology
courses.description: Individual supervised work in a area of interest in medical technology.

courses.name: Cytology of the Female Genital Tract
courses.description: A definitive study by means of light microscopy of normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring within the female genital tract along with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Cytology of Respiratory Tract
courses.description: A definitive study by means of light microscopy of normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring with the respiratory tract along with immunohistologic correlation. Prerequisitez: senior standing and instructor's consent.

courses.name: Cytology of Urinary Tract
courses.description: A definitive study by means of light microscopy of normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring within the urinary tract along with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Cytology of Gastrointestinal Tract
courses.description: A definitive study by means of light microscopy of normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring within the gastrointestinal tract along with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Cytology of Body Fluids
courses.description: A definitive study of light microscopy of normal and abnormal cellular   changes occurring within body fluid along with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Cytology of Breast
courses.description: A definitive study by means of light microscopy of normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring within the breast with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology
courses.description: A definitive study by means of light microscopy of normal and abnormal cellular changes occurring within the fine needle aspirations from various body sites along with histologic correlation.

courses.name: Special Procedures in Cytology
courses.description: Study of hematologic findings in body fluid cytology: chromosome cultures and karyotyping. Emphasizing sex-related abnormalities; hormonal evaluation of smears from the female genital tract and their clinical significance.

courses.name: Clinical Management
courses.description: Procedures and processes helpful in operating in cytology laboratory, especially at the supervisory level.

courses.name: Technical Application with Research in Cytotechnology
courses.description: Research is an area of interest in cytology resulting in a written and oral presentation.

courses.name: Cytologic Preparation
courses.description: Independent applications of techniques used to prepare cytologic material.

courses.name: Practical Cytotechnology
courses.description: Independent application of techniques used to examine cytology material an manage a cytology laboratory.

courses.name: Problems in Cytotechnology
courses.description: Individual supervised work in an area of interest in cytology.

courses.name: Elementary Histology
courses.description: Simplified gross and microscopic anatomy of normal organs and tissues   commonly found in the routine histopathology laboratory.

courses.name: Basic Histotechnology
courses.description: Theories and technical application of procedures used in the preparation of   tissue sections and slides of microscopic examination; including instrumentation, fixation, dehydration, clearing infiltration, embedding, mirotomy, H&E staining and coverslipping.

courses.name: Special Staining Techniques
courses.description: Principles and procedures for special staining techniques for carbohydrates,   connective tissues, blood, fat and lipids, pigments and minerals, bacteria and fungi, nerve, and other special cell stains.

courses.name: Applied Histotechnology
courses.description: Application of basic histological techniques in the preparation of histologic   sections and slides in a clinical setting.

courses.name: Research and Instructional Techniques
courses.description: Involves library and laboratory search. Includes development of oral and  written communications skills.
courses.prerequisites: senior students admitted to Histotechnology Curriculum

courses.name: Clinical Management
courses.description: Supervisory techniques and procedures helpful in operating a histopathology  laboratory: including laboratory safety, workload recording, and personnel management in a laboratory situation.

courses.name: Basic Disease Processes
courses.description: Special readings and discussions of basic disease processes of interest  to the anatomic pathology laboratory.

courses.name: Advances Histotechnology
courses.description: Advanced and specialized techniques used in the preparation and processing   of muscle, nerve and rectal biopsies; special techniques in cytology; electron microscopy; enzyme and immunohistochemistry; plastic embedding and neuropathologic techniques.

courses.name: Problems in Histotechnology
courses.description: Individual supervised work in a specialized area of histotechnology.

courses.name: General Pathology
courses.description: Basic pathological mechanisms of human disease. Introductory principles of clinical laboratory measurements of altered organ system function studied.
courses.prerequisites: PTH_AS 7200, PTH_AS 7220, PTH_AS 7310; and instructor's consent

courses.name: General Pathology Laboratory
courses.description: Gross and microscopic applied study of basic pathological disease mechanisms. Laboratory assessment of these basic disease mechanisms.
courses.prerequisites: PTH_AS 7200, PTH_AS 7220, PTH_AS 7310; or the equivalents; and instructor's consent

courses.name: Seminar in Pathology and Anatomical Sciences
courses.description: Presentation and discussion of original investigations and current literature.

courses.name: Forensic Pathology and Death Investigation
courses.description: Forensic Pathology and Death Investigation.

courses.name: Forensic Pathology and Death Investigation - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Forensic Pathology and Death Investigation.

courses.name: Gross Human Anatomy (The Health Professions)
courses.description: Gross structure and neuroanatomy of the human body; dissection of extremities, back, head, neck abdomen and thorax.

courses.name: Interpretations of Lab Procedures in Primary Health Care
courses.description: Discussion and analysis of selected laboratory test procedures used in office and clinic settings involved with primary health care.
courses.prerequisites: graduate level Physiology course and departmental consent

courses.name: ABS Advanced Medical Neurosciences
courses.description: ABS Advanced Medical Neurosciences

courses.name: ABS Pathology/Anatomical Science Research
courses.description: ABS Pathology/Anatomical Science Research

courses.name: ABS Pathology/Anatomical Science Research and Review
courses.description: ABS Pathology/Anatomical Science Research and Review

courses.name: ABS Science Anatomical Science Teaching
courses.description: ABS Science Anatomical Science Teaching

courses.name: ABS Surgical Anatomy
courses.description: ABS Surgical Anatomy

courses.name: ABS Surgical Anatomy of the Head and Neck
courses.description: ABS Surgical Anatomy of the Head and Neck

courses.name: ABS Surgical Anatomy of the Back and Limbs
courses.description: ABS Surgical Anatomy of the Back and Limbs

courses.name: ABS Surgical Anatomy of the Pelvis and Perinium
courses.description: ABS Surgical Anatomy of the Pelvis and Perinium

courses.name: Anatomic Pathology
courses.description: Anatomic Pathology

courses.name: Clinical Pathology
courses.description: Clinical Pathology

courses.name: Forensic Pathology
courses.description: Forensic Pathology

courses.name: Anatomic/Clinical Pathology
courses.description: Anatomic/Clinical Pathology

courses.name: Anatomy Elective
courses.description: Anatomy Elective

courses.name: Anatomic Pathology Two-Week
courses.description: This is a two week rotation. Students will learn how to integrate information and apply previously acquired knowledge and concepts to the assessment and interpretation of surgical pathology, cytopathology, and/or autopsy cases. Students will learn about the procedures necessary to arrive at anatomic pathology diagnoses and the work that goes into specimen processing and examination so as to produce diagnoses.
courses.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school

courses.name: Clinical Pathology - Laboratory Medicine
courses.description: Students will learn how to integrate information and apply previously acquired knowledge and concepts to the assessment and interpretation of clinical laboratory tests. Students will learn about the procedures necessary to arrive at clinical pathology diagnoses and the work that goes into specimen processing and examination so as to produce diagnoses.
courses.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school

courses.name: Forensic Pathology and Death Investigation
courses.description: Summary of Forensic Death Investigation from beginning to end. Will include some of the current laboratory techniques seen on "CSI" Team taught by experts in the fields including medical examiners, death investigators, forensic anthropologists, police CSI teams, lawyers and others.

courses.name: Human Histology and Organology
courses.description: Detailed study of cytology, histology and microscopic anatomy.
courses.prerequisites: 10 hours of Biological Sciences and instructor's consent

courses.name: Gross Human Anatomy (The Health Professions)
courses.description: Gross/human structure through dissection.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into Physical Therapy Programs or instructor's consent

courses.name: Mammalian Reproduction
courses.description: Reproduction in mammals, with emphasis on the neuroendocrine control of the hormones involved in reproductive process: biosyntheses, biologic actions, role.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing in one of Animal, Biologic, Medical, or Veterinary Sciences, instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Pathology
courses.description: Demonstration and simulation study of gross, microscopic and clinical laboratory pathology of major human organ systems.
courses.prerequisites: PTH_AS 4200 and PTH_AS 4205 or equivalent and instructor's consent

courses.name: Autonomic Nervous System
courses.description: A comprehensive consideration of the autonomic nervous system in man, with emphasis on morphology.
courses.prerequisites: PTH_AS 2201, Comparative Anatomy or equivalent, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Hematopoietic Organs
courses.description: Morphological and functional relationships of the blood-forming organs.

courses.name: Advanced Pathology Laboratory
courses.description: Demonstration and simulation and character of work depend upon needs, qualifications, and of major human organ systems.
courses.prerequisites: PTH_AS 4200 and PTH_AS 4205 or equivalent and instructor's consent

courses.name: Seminars in Translational Medicine
courses.description: Students participate in regular seminars and discussion groups with other students interested in clinical and translational sciences. Students, working together with faculty in biomedical sciences and those working in clinical and translational fields, identify seminar topics. Learning objectives and written assignments are arranged on an individual basis. The course is open to all graduate level students and students enrolled in professional schools, for 0-5 credit hours, with instructor's approval. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Precision Medicine Informatics
courses.description: This course will introduce students with the theoretical and practical aspects of precision medicine informatics. Topics include: complex diseases, computational genomics/proteomics, informatics of molecular interactions and biological pathways, somatic mutations, signal transduction and cancer, biomarker discovery, machine learning and data mining for PMI, networks methods for PMI, knowledge representation and reasoning for PMI. The course will consist of a set of didactic lectures, computational assignments, in-class demonstrations of PMI methods and discussions of recent publications. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: INFOINST 8005 with C or better or INFOINST 7010 with C or better or instructor's consent

courses.name: Comparative Pathology
courses.description: (same as V_PBIO 8430). Biochemical and morphologic lesions related to the mechanism of disease expression in plants and animals.

courses.name: Current Issues in Anatomical Sciences
courses.description: Survey of the recent literature in integrative anatomy, including functional, evolutionary, developmental and translational anatomy, conducted through readings and discussion.  Grade determined by participation and presentation of weekly readings.  May be repeated for a maximum of 10 hours.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Pathology
courses.description: Open only to properly qualified graduate students, with counsel of faculty.  Focus of MS-related research in evolutionary morphology, genomics, neuroscience, pathobiology or laboratory sciences.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Evolutionary Biology
courses.description: Principles of modern evolutionary biology.  Topics include: phylogeny, palebiology, developmental processes, genetic and phenotypic variation, form and function, speculation, macroevolution, and molecular mechanisms.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Evolutionary Morphology
courses.description: This course is a survey of the fundamentals of modern evolutionary morphology.  Topics will include: patterns of vertebrate evolution, comparative methods, development and ontogeny, constraint, functional morphology, evolutionary innovations, and experimental methods.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Human Anatomy: Back and Upper Limb
courses.description: Developmental, gross, and clinical anatomy of the human back and upper limb, including skeletal, muscular, nervous, and vascular tissues. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Human Anatomy: Thorax and Abdomen
courses.description: Developmental, gross, and clinical anatomy of the human thorax and abdomen. Graded on an A-F basis only.

courses.name: Human Anatomy: Head, Neck and Neuroanatomy
courses.description: Developmental, gross and clinical anatomy of the human head, neck and neuoranatomy. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Human Anatomy: Pelvis and Lower Limb
courses.description: Developmental, gross and clinical anatomy of the human pelvis and lower limb. Graded A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Pathology and Anatomical Sciences
courses.description: Regions or systems which may include developmental, microscopic, and gross anatomy.

courses.name: Research in Pathology and Anatomical Sciences
courses.description: Research unrelated to thesis work in evolutionary morphology, genomics, neuroscience, pathobiology or laboratory sciences.

courses.name: Anatomy of the Human Nervous System
courses.description: A comprehensive consideration of the morphology of the nervous system, emphasizing correlation of structure and function.
courses.prerequisites: PTH_AS 2201, Comparative Anatomy or equivalent, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Human Anatomy Teaching Practicum
courses.description: Provides practical experience teaching clinically oriented human anatomy in lecture and laboratory settings. For students pursuing doctoral degrees in Pathobiology. Enrollement is limited to students who have completed PTH_AS 8201, PTH_AS 8202, PTH_AS 8203, and PTH_AS 8204. Graded on S/U basis only. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Seminar in Translational Neuroscience
courses.description: Students participate in seminars and discussion groups.  Masters students identify seminar topics and present existing data with findings.  PhD students identify seminar topics, conduct research and present findings.  Learning objective and written assignments are arranged individuality.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Research in Pathology and Anatomical Sciences
courses.description: Open only to properly qualified graduate students, with counsel of faculty.  Focus of PhD-related research in evolutionary morphology, genomics, neuroscience or pathobiology.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Research in Pathology and Anatomical Sciences
courses.description: Open only with instructor's consent.  Courses with specialized lectures in various topics such as evolutionary morphology, genomics, neuroscience and pathobiology, depending on faculty expertise and student demand.  Graded on S/U basis only.
